## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 358, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Pure Mathematics 3 (P3)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 555, 910, 586]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 586, 595, 601]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 601, 606, 616]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 630, 609, 646]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 646, 757, 661]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 661, 440, 676]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 77, 94, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Expand \(\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(1 + 6x)}}\) in ascending powers of \(x\), up to and including the term in \(x^3\), simplifying the coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 437, 92]]<|/det|>
The parametric equations of a curve are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 100, 616, 119]]<|/det|>
\[x = \ln \cos \theta ,\quad y = 3\theta -\tan \theta ,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 266, 145]]<|/det|>
where \(0\leqslant \theta < \frac{1}{2}\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 163, 156, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 161, 393, 190]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\) in terms of \(\tan \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 168, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 74, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the exact \(y\)-coordinate of the point on the curve at which the gradient of the normal is equal to 1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 154, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 73, 562, 92]]<|/det|>
Verify by calculation that \(x\) lies between 1 and 1.5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 410, 193, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 411, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative formula based on the equation in part (i) to determine \(x\) correct to 3 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 5 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 428, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The plane with equation \(2x + 2y - z = 5\) is denoted by \(m\). Relative to the origin \(O\), the points \(A\) and \(B\) have coordinates (3, 4, 0) and \((-1, 0, 2)\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 549, 138]]<|/det|>
Show that the plane \(m\) bisects \(AB\) at right angles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
A second plane \(p\) is parallel to \(m\) and nearer to \(O\). The perpendicular distance between the planes is 1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 104, 154, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 104, 732, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of \(p\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 672, 92]]<|/det|>
**Throughout this question the use of a calculator is not permitted.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 702, 123]]<|/det|>
The complex numbers \(u\) and \(w\) are defined by \(u = - 1 + 7\mathrm{i}\) and \(w = 3 + 4\mathrm{i}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 134, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Showing all your working, find in the form \(x + \mathrm{i}y\), where \(x\) and \(y\) are real, the complex numbers

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 152, 280, 172]]<|/det|>
\(u - 2w\) and \(\frac{u}{w}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 156, 920, 175]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 602, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
In an Argand diagram with origin \(O\), the points \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) represent the complex numbers \(u\), \(w\) and \(u - 2w\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 650, 153, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 650, 384, 668]]<|/det|>
Prove that angle \(AOB = \frac{1}{4}\pi\).

<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 75, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
By first expanding \(2\sin (x - 30^{\circ})\), express \(2\sin (x - 30^{\circ}) - \cos x\) in the form \(R\sin (x - \alpha)\), where \(R > 0\) and \(0^{\circ}< \alpha < 90^{\circ}\). Give the exact value of \(R\) and the value of \(\alpha\) correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 73, 156, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 72, 462, 102]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{1}{x(2x + 3)}\) in partial fractions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 77, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 528, 186, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 524, 583, 546]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) satisfy the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 551, 568, 581]]<|/det|>
\[x(2x + 3)\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = y,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 588, 920, 625]]<|/det|>
and it is given that \(y = 1\) when \(x = 1\). Solve the differential equation and calculate the value of \(y\) when \(x = 9\), giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 605, 920, 624]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 751, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of \(M\). Give your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
